summary: A tutorial on how to use the 'A Touch of Venus' kit.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by a title card displaying the text "A Touch of Venus" in white font against a black background. The title card also features a logo in the top right corner, depicting a stylized figure hugging a globe with stars, accompanied by the text "A Touch of the Universe." The scene transitions to a webpage with a black background, showcasing the same logo and title "A Touch of the Universe" in white font. The webpage includes a navigation menu with options such as "Home," "Project," "Team," "Downloads," "Tutorials," "Gallery," "Contact," and "Español Italiano." Below the title, there is a description of the project, explaining that "A Touch of the Universe" is a non-profit initiative aimed at providing a tactile astronomy kit for children with vision impairments. The kit is designed to be sent to educators and teachers in underdeveloped countries, with the first 30 kits already dispatched to America, Asia, and Africa. The webpage also mentions an extension of the project, "A Touch of Venus," which includes a 3D tactile globe, an activity book, and video resources. The video concludes with the webpage URL "https://astrok.it.uv.es" displayed at the bottom of the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a brief musical interlude, featuring a gentle and somewhat uplifting mood, possibly from a piano or a similar keyboard instrument. This transitions into a woman's voice, speaking in an instructional tone, introducing a video tutorial about how to use materials from "A Touch of Venus Kit." She mentions these materials are part of resources developed for the "A Touch of the Universe" project, and can be used regardless of "their sight capacity." She states all elements of the kit can be downloaded from the website.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to a logo featuring the letters "OAD" surrounded by colorful circles and dots, representing the International Astronomical Union and the Office of Astronomy for Development. The scene then shifts to a close-up of a document titled "Introduction to the Kit Contents," detailing the contents of the "A Touch of Venus" kit, which includes a Venus model, an activity book, and a Venus model with feature names. The document is placed on a table next to a globe and a notebook. The video then shows a close-up of the Venus model, highlighting its textured surface and features. Following this, the activity book titled "A Touch of Venus Activity Book" is displayed, listing the authors and mentioning that it is funded by the IAU Office of Astronomy for Development. The final scene features the Venus model with feature names, accompanied by a blue drawstring bag with the text "A Touch of Venus" printed on it. The video provides a comprehensive overview of the "A Touch of Venus" kit, emphasizing its educational and astronomical significance.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a female speaker describing a kit resulting from collaboration and funding from the International Astronomical Union's Office of Astronomy for Development, before proceeding to list the contents of the kit: a presentation letter, a Venus tactile lobe, an activity book in Braille and normal printing with suggestions for using the Venus globe, and an annotated map with snapshots of the digital model with feature names. The speaker maintains a neutral and informative tone throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a series of items related to a project titled "A Touch of Venus," which is a Venus model with feature names. The items are displayed on a wooden surface, including a blue tote bag with the project's logo and text, a white paper with the project's title and a diagram of Venus, and a white bracelet with red and blue patterns. The paper also mentions the project's funding by the IAU Office of Astronomy for Development (OAD) and the Creative Commons license under which it is shared. The video transitions to show the bracelet laid out on a brown paper with the same project logo and text, emphasizing the collaboration between the Observatorio Astronómico de la Universidad de Valencia and the University of Valencia. The final frame focuses on the blue tote bag, highlighting the project's branding and the logos of the collaborating institutions. The overall setting is a simple, clean workspace, with the items neatly arranged to showcase the project's details and affiliations.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker describing a "measuring lace" 28 centimeters long with knots every 7 centimeters, designed to measure distances on a globe both by touch and visually. She further describes a bag used to carry the globe and activity book.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a table with various items, including a model of a planet, a booklet, a certificate, a bracelet, and a tote bag with a cookie design. The table is set against a plain wall with a whiteboard in the background. The items are neatly arranged, and the scene is static, with no visible movement or action. The video includes a text overlay at the bottom of the screen, displaying a URL: "https://astrok.it.uv.es," which suggests a connection to an educational or scientific resource. The overall atmosphere is educational and informative, with the items on the table likely related to astronomy or space exploration. The video maintains a consistent visual presentation throughout, with no significant changes in the arrangement of the items or the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker promoting resources like "Venus tactile glow", "activity book", and a document with "snapshots", mentioning they can be downloaded from the website "A Touch of the Universe". She then suggests to "start with the Venus model." The tone is informative and friendly.  A moment later, it transitions to silence.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a yellow, textured spherical object resembling a planet, placed on a blue base on a light-colored table. The object has a rough surface with various indentations and a prominent circular feature on its top. The background is a plain, light-colored wall with a dark vertical line, possibly a door frame. The object rotates slowly, revealing its textured surface and the circular feature from different angles. The scene then transitions to a close-up of an open book on the same table. The book contains text and an image of the yellow spherical object. The text on the left page reads "1. EXPLORING THE TACTILE VENUS MODEL," with an objective, duration, materials, and activity description. The right page continues with steps for the activity, including presenting the tactile Venus model to participants and demonstrating how to identify the North Pole. The video concludes with a focus on the book, emphasizing the educational content related to the tactile Venus model.
events_list.audio_caption: A woman speaks in an informative tone, describing the polar caps on a globe of Venus, the North Pole, the South Pole (marked with a logo), and a meridian, suggesting these elements can aid in exploration. She mentions an activity book with suggested activities for the model.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of an open notebook on a wooden table, displaying a page titled "1. EXPLORING THE TACTILE VENUS MODEL." The page outlines the objective, duration, materials, and activity description for an educational exercise involving a tactile Venus model. The objective is to familiarize participants with the Venus tactile model by exploring it and learning how to use it. The duration is 15 minutes, and the materials required are a tactile Venus model, measuring lace with knots. The activity description includes two steps: presenting the tactile Venus to participants and demonstrating how to identify the North Pole by locating the smooth shape of one of the polar caps. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a person's hands holding a tactile Venus model, which is a textured, spherical object resembling the planet Venus. The person is using a measuring lace with red and white patterns to measure the model, demonstrating the tactile exploration process described in the notebook. The background shows the open notebook with the activity description visible, reinforcing the educational context of the exercise. The video emphasizes the tactile exploration of the Venus model, highlighting the hands-on learning experience.
events_list.audio_caption: A single female speaker presents a set of instructions in a calm, informational tone, mentioning that "all of them follow the same structure." She describes the information each activity provides, including its goal, approximate duration, required materials, the procedure, and suggestions for analysis. She then introduces the first activity, focusing on familiarizing oneself with the model, demonstrating the positions of the poles, and measuring with a measuring lace. The speaker uses examples, stating, "the equator of the planet is located at about two knots away from the poles." She also explains conventions, like moving east, with "the north pole on top." A gentle, background music accompanies the speech.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a person's hands holding a textured, orange spherical object resembling a model of Venus, with a spiral-bound notebook open beside it. The notebook contains text detailing an educational activity about Venus, including objectives, materials, and procedures. The person uses a ribbon to mark specific points on the model, indicating a tactile exploration of the planet's surface. The scene transitions to the model being partially covered with a blue cloth, with the notebook still open to a page titled "Venus - Global Warming," suggesting a shift in the activity's focus. The cloth is then removed, revealing the model again, and the notebook is opened to a page titled "Venus - Phases," indicating a continuation of the educational exploration. Throughout the video, the setting remains consistent, with a wooden table and a neutral background, emphasizing the educational and tactile nature of the activity.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with calm and soothing background music. A woman speaking with a pleasant and informative tone introduces "Activity Two" and mentions the retrograde rotation of Venus, which is unique among the planets in our solar system. Moving onto "Activity Three", she describes the focus as learning about global warming, which was first detected on Venus. She further discusses a cloth to simulate the planet's thick atmosphere for this activity. Moving on, she presents "Activity Four" and explains that the faces of Venus are simulated using a black cloth. The audio clip ends with the background music.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a yellow, textured spherical object resembling a planet, with a measuring tape wrapped around it. A person's hands are seen adjusting the tape, which has a red and white pattern, around the object. The background features an open book with text, suggesting an educational or instructional setting. The person continues to manipulate the tape, indicating a measurement or demonstration process. The scene transitions to a wider shot, showing the object on a table with the book and additional materials, including printed images of the planet. The video then focuses on the open book, displaying text and images related to the planet, with the title "Venus: modeling Volcanoes" visible. The text outlines objectives, materials, and activity procedures, emphasizing an educational activity involving the creation of a shield volcano model. The video concludes with a static shot of the book and materials, reinforcing the instructional context.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker discussing Activity Five. Speaking in an instructional tone, she highlights the importance of volcanic activity on Venus and suggests that the measuring lace helps locate features like mountain ranges and volcanoes, providing examples of Maxwell Montes and volcanoes near Rhea Mons and Theia Mons. She mentions a map with snapshots to help locate important features. The speaker then transitions to Activity Six, explaining how to demonstrate the types of volcanoes in Venus and construct a shield volcano using materials like plasticine. She mentions the location document snapshots can help.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a table displaying an open book and a sheet of paper with images of a spherical object, possibly a model of a celestial body. The book is titled "6. VENUS: modeling Volcanoes," with instructions for an activity involving creating a shield volcano model. The scene transitions to a person measuring a textured, orange spherical object resembling a model of Venus with a measuring tape. The person's hands are visible, and the background includes a notebook with text detailing the activity's procedure. The person then points to a specific feature on the model, likely a volcano, emphasizing its significance. The video focuses on the educational demonstration of the Venus model, highlighting the activity's objective to demonstrate the characteristics of Venus's surface.
events_list.audio_caption: A female speaker explains how to locate points of interest on a model of a planet, providing instructions and examples in a clear and instructional tone. She uses terms like "north pole" and "meridian" and explains how to measure from those points. The speaker continues, giving additional examples of locations on the model.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person interacting with a tactile model of Venus, a planet with a textured surface resembling craters and volcanic features. The model is placed on a table next to an open notebook with text detailing Venus-related information, including its geological features and mythological associations. The person's hands are shown pointing to and touching various parts of the model, emphasizing its topographical details. The notebook contains educational content, with sections discussing Venus's surface characteristics, such as highlands and craters, and its mythological connections to goddesses like Aphrodite and Ishtar. The person uses a measuring tape to demonstrate the model's size, providing a sense of scale. The video's setting is an indoor environment, likely an educational or classroom space, with a focus on hands-on learning and exploration of planetary features. The atmosphere is one of curiosity and engagement, as the person actively examines and explains the tactile model's features.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a calm female voice describing the activities related to craters and coronae on Venus, emphasizing female characters and how geological formations are named after them. She uses Atalanta as an example and the Joliot-Curie crater. The tone is instructional and encouraging, inviting feedback and suggestions. The clip is then mixed with light, calm background music throughout, suggesting a peaceful or educational setting.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a display of various items on a table, including a model of Venus, a brochure, a certificate, a bracelet, and a tote bag with the text "A Touch of the Universe." The website "https://astrok.it.uv.es" is visible at the bottom of the frame. The scene transitions to a black screen with the text "A Touch of Venus" in white, accompanied by a logo of a person touching a planet. The video then credits the creators and contributors, listing names and roles such as script, photography, music, voice over, editing, recording, and technical support. Logos of the University of Valencia, Observatory Astronomic, and other organizations are displayed at the bottom. The video concludes with the same black screen and credits, emphasizing the collaborative effort behind the project.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a female speaker calmly stating, "You can contact us through the contact form." She further clarifies that the form can be found on "the Attach of the Universe website." Background music follows, which sets a reflective and possibly wondrous mood, reminiscent of music used in science documentaries, with synthesized instruments being prominent.
